DOCNAME: CASE OF BOYLE AND RICE v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 8;No violation of Art. 13;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , PERSON and PERSON , are NORP citizens born in DATE and DATE respectively . In DATE , the first applicant was sentenced in GPE to life imprisonment for murder . He received a number of subsequent prison sentences in DATE and DATE for prison breaking , attempted murder of a prison officer and assault on prison staff . The second applicant is the first applicant ’s wife and a doctor by profession .

CARDINAL . In DATE , Mr. PERSON was removed from ORG to a ORG in FAC . ORG had been set up on an experimental basis to treat selected long - term prisoners and prisoners with violent propensities ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The ORG had a maximum of CARDINAL prisoners and was characterised by a more liberal regime . Mr. PERSON played a prominent role in facilitating the success of ORG . In particular , he discovered that he had special abilities in working with people and in sculpture , writing and other areas of artistic activity .

While in ORG , Mr. PERSON was allowed , amongst other things , to write and receive uncensored mail , to have DATE access to visitors and to use a telephone . He was thereby able to meet his wife , talk to her on the telephone and correspond with her without being subject to the normal restrictions . He also had the opportunity to go out of the prison without escort .

CARDINAL . In DATE , Mr. PERSON was advised by ORG that he was to be released on licence in DATE and that he was to be transferred to PERSON , GPE , to undergo a pre - release programme . He was informed that he would serve his time there on the same terms and conditions as other prisoners . It was considered that , although the regime there was on traditional lines , ORG would be more beneficial to Mr. PERSON during the period leading to his eventual release than other alternatives , for example PERSON Open Prison ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The factors governing the choice included the desirability of his occupying a single cell rather than being in a dormitory ; the availability of suitable day - time work for him and of facilities for continuing his studies and his artistic work ; and access to suitable educational and vocational opportunities for his pre - release training . Mr. PERSON himself had in fact stated in written submissions in DATE that , if he could not remain at PERSON for his pre - release programme , he would prefer training from GPE rather than PERSON .
In DATE , he was transferred to a Training for Freedom Hostel within the prison ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . He was released on DATE .
As from DATE until his release , he was in the lowest security category ( Category D ) .

CARDINAL . The applicants’ complaints to ORG in so far as relevant to the present proceedings all related to the period DATE and DATE when Mr. PERSON was subject to the ordinary prison regime at ORG . The facts surrounding those grievances are briefly set out in the following paragraphs .

CARDINAL . During the relevant period the normal rules regarding the sending and payment of correspondence were applied to Mr. PERSON ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) . The postage of CARDINAL - page letter per week was paid for out of public funds . He was able to pay for other letters out of his prison earnings of £ MONEY per week but not out of his general financial resources . In a letter of DATE from his solicitors to the Secretary of ORG for GPE , a complaint was made that because he found it necessary to spend MONEY per week out of his earnings to supplement his ( mainly ) vegetarian diet by buying oatmeal cakes as the prison service provided only white bread , the number of letters he was able to send was restricted . A full vegetarian diet was available at FAC and no complaint was made by Mr. PERSON to the Governor or to the Secretary of ORG as to its adequacy .

CARDINAL . Mr. PERSON ’s incoming and outgoing mail was controlled by the prison authorities in accordance with the normal practice followed at the prison ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The applicants also asserted before the Commission that on occasions the prison censorship officer read out aloud in front of other inmates letters from Mrs. PERSON , laughing or making comments about their contents . However , Mr. PERSON did not make any complaint to ORG or the Secretary of ORG regarding the manner in which his mail was read , in particular about its being read aloud , although the fact of his mail being screened was the subject of complaint in his solicitors’ letter of DATE .

CARDINAL . In DATE , a letter to a friend of his , Mr. PERSON , was stopped by the Prison Governor on the ground that Mr. PERSON was a " media personality " . Mr. PERSON petitioned the Secretary of ORG regarding this matter , but his petition was rejected on the basis that there was a general prohibition of the passing on by a prisoner of material intended for publication or for use on wireless or television ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The Government have subsequently acknowledged that in fact this rule was applied in error , since , although the letter in question was addressed to a person connected with the public media , it was a personal one which Mr. PERSON should have been allowed to send .

CARDINAL . Mr. PERSON was entitled to receive visits in accordance with the normal rules applied in LOC ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . Consequently , as pointed out in his solicitors’ letter of DATE , he was permitted TIME visiting time DATE under close supervision in a crowded visiting hall . He used this time to meet his wife , with the result that he was not able to see the other members of his family .

He was able to benefit from the special escorted leave scheme and visited his home on CARDINAL occasions , albeit under the constant supervision of an officer in accordance with the scheme ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
As from DATE , he was given a special licence to do unescorted community work outside the prison , initially for DATE and subsequently for DATE .

CARDINAL . The solicitors for Mr. and Mrs. PERSON also raised with the Secretary of ORG a general objection that Mr. PERSON ’s treatment at FAC was markedly less favourable than his treatment at ORG and also in comparison with other Category D prisoners elsewhere under the penal system .
By reply dated DATE , the Secretary of ORG rejected this and the other complaints made in the solicitors’ letter of DATE .

Mr. PERSON also complained through his Member of ORG to the Parliamentary Commissioner for ORG ( the ORG - see paragraph DATE below ) about various aspects of his treatment at FAC . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE , the ORG stated that he could not uphold Mr. PERSON ’s complaints . He stated , inter alia :

" From the details that Mr. PERSON has given , his correspondence , special escorted leave , and visits appear to have been dealt with correctly in accordance with current rules , however dissatisfied he may be with those rules . I think it is fair to say that much of Mr. PERSON ’s complaint reflects his disagreement with those rules and with their application to him at this stage of his sentence . The rules are of course a matter for ORG and in the absence of evidence of maladministration I am precluded by LAW from questioning the ORG ’s discretion in applying them . "
CARDINAL . The applicants , PERSON and PERSON , are NORP citizens born in DATE and DATE respectively .

PERSON was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder in DATE . He served his sentence in GPE and GPE Prisons until DATE . From DATE , he was detained as a Category D prisoner ( that is , the lowest security category ) at FAC . He was moved to ORG within the prison ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) on DATE and was released on licence on DATE . He had requested to serve the latter part of his sentence in GPE rather than , for example , in FAC ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) because he wanted , prior to his release , to have the benefit of further education courses which were not available from PERSON .

PERSON is the first - named applicant ’s father and lives at GPE , QUANTITY from GPE . At the relevant time he was seriously ill - having been in bad health for some DATE - and unable to walk or travel .
CARDINAL . During his period in LOC , PERSON enjoyed the normal entitlement to visits applicable at the prison .

He petitioned the Secretary of ORG for GPE on CARDINAL DATE requesting a home visit to his father . The petition indicated that his father had been " ill for a considerable period " , but not that he was dangerously ill , which would have made him eligible for compassionate leave ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . His request was therefore refused on CARDINAL DATE . The decision recommended him to make the effort to get a member of staff to take him out of prison under the special escorted leave scheme ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . It appears , however , that he experienced difficulty in finding a prison officer to accompany him on special escorted leave . Although PERSON was not able to visit his father during the relevant period , he was permitted to attend , without an escort , a college to follow an educational course DATE a week and also a centre where he was doing community work . He had previously been granted a home visit in DATE and prior to the commencement of the Training for Freedom programme he spent DATE on home leave in DATE .
In a letter dated DATE in reply to a letter of DATE from Mr. PERSON ’s Member of ORG , the Under Secretary of ORG at ORG explained the reasons for the refusal of compassionate leave :

" ... Each application is considered on its merits and on the basis of medical and social work reports . Mr. PERSON ’s application for a special visit was considered in the usual way but it was decided that it did not meet the required conditions . Mr. PERSON was advised that if his father ’s condition deteriorated he should make a further request . It is necessary , to prevent abuse of the arrangements , to maintain a strict and entirely consistent approach to applications for compassionate visits from all prisoners and the fact that a prisoner is being released for educational or other purposes does not affect consideration of the merits of his application or remove the need for the normal criteria to be met . ... Mr. PERSON is expected to transfer to the formal Training for Freedom ( TFF ) in DATE . Prior to that he will have a DATE home leave and while on ORG he will have DATE which he may spend at home . I feel that it would be quite wrong , before that stage is reached , to make a special exception in Mr. PERSON ’s case and circumvent the rules in relation to either a compassionate visit or a special escorted leave . "
CARDINAL . On DATE , the solicitors acting for PERSON wrote to the Secretary of ORG complaining about
- the alleged stopping by the prison authorities of a number of letters addressed to themselves , his Member of ORG , his former counsel and his family ;

- his limited prison visiting entitlement , which , as regards maintenance of family contacts , was said to discriminate against him in comparison with other prisoners who were in Category D but detained in open conditions ; and
- the refusal to grant compassionate leave .
The reply of DATE sent on behalf of the Secretary of ORG rejected all the various complaints raised . In particular , it was pointed out that all his mail had been posted .

CARDINAL . The prison system in GPE is governed by ORG " LAW " ) . Under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW , general control and superintendance over prisons in GPE are vested in the Secretary of ORG for GPE .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act empowers the Secretary of ORG to " make rules for the regulation and management of prisons ... and for the classification , treatment , employment , discipline and control of persons required to be detained therein " . This power is exercisable by statutory instrument . A draft of any statutory instrument made under LAW has to be laid before ORG ( section CARDINAL ) . Statutory instruments are categorised by domestic law as subordinate legislation ( LAW ) . Subordinate legislation is recognised at common law to have the full force and effect of legislation made by ORG ( see GPE ’s ORG , CARDINALth ed . , vol . CARDINAL , para . CARDINAL ) . Statutory instruments such as ORG are made public .

In exercise of his powers under LAW of LAW , the Secretary of ORG has made the Prison ( GPE ) Rules DATE ( Statutory Instrument CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ( " the Prison Rules " ) , which have been amended periodically .

In supplement of ORG , the Secretary of ORG , in the exercise of his general jurisdiction over prisons and of various powers conferred in the Prison Rules themselves , issues instructions to the Governors of prisons by way of administrative orders referred to as " Standing Orders " . At the relevant time , the text of the Standing Orders themselves was not made public . However , an Abstract of Rules and Regulations for Convicted Prisoners ( " the Abstract " ) containing information about the content of ORG and Standing Orders was made available to convicted prisoners .
CARDINAL . Rule CARDINAL of ORG provides , inter alia :

" ( CARDINAL ) Every prisoner shall be allowed to write and to receive a letter on his admission , and shall thereafter be allowed to write and to receive letters and to receive visits at intervals laid down by the Secretary of ORG . The intervals so prescribed may be extended as a punishment for misconduct , but shall not be extended so as to preclude a prisoner from writing and receiving a letter , and receiving a visit , DATE .

( CARDINAL ) Subject to the provisions of Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) every letter to or from a prisoner shall be read by the Governor or by an officer deputed by him for that purpose and it shall be within the discretion of the Governor to stop any letter if he considers that the contents are objectionable . "
At the relevant time , these provisions were supplemented by Standing Orders Ic.CARDINAL to CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . Thus , Standing Order Ic.CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) specified :
" Prisoners will be granted the privilege of writing letters on the following scale :
( a ) All convicted prisoners ... are allowed to write CARDINAL letter DATE to their relatives and friends , the postage of which will be paid out of public funds . ...

( d ) Postage of additional letters may be met from earnings ; the use of private cash from sources other than earnings should not be allowed for this purpose . Before an inmate is allowed to write extra letters he should submit for the Governor ’s approval a list of persons with whom he intends to correspond . Additions to or deletions from the list will be at the Governor ’s discretion .

No limit was placed on the number of additional letters that might be sent . The content of the relevant provisions of the Standing Orders was made known to prisoners in paragraph CARDINAL of the Abstract .
CARDINAL . Standing Order Ic.CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) dealt with the reading of correspondence under Prison Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) :

" In the case of the great majority of letters , where neither the prisoner nor his offence is of notoriety , and the correspondent is a wife or near relative , it is not necessary that every letter should be read through . It will usually suffice to glance at the contents and see they are of usual domestic and personal nature . There will , however , always be certain prisoners whose correspondence requires to be thoroughly examined , and it will be for the Governor to settle who these are and to instruct the officer who deals with the letters accordingly . "
Standing Order Ic.CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) further provided ( as regards incoming mail ) :
" In no circumstances should the contents of a letter to a prisoner or inmate be referred to in the hearing of another inmate . "
CARDINAL . Standing Order Ic.CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) dealt with the exercise of the Governor ’s discretion under LAW ) to stop " objectionable " letters . It stated :

" All ordinary matter , including news of public events , should be passed . Comment by a prisoner on his own conviction and sentence is not objectionable if expressed in proper terms . Objectionable matter falls within narrow limits , viz .
( c ) Matter intended for insertion in the ORG , for publication or for use on wireless or television ( with the exception of the magazine ‘ GPE ) .

Since the relevant time , new Standing Orders on ORG correspondence have been introduced in GPE in light of ORG Rights’ judgment of DATE in the case of Silver and Others ( Series A no . CARDINAL ) . The restrictions on correspondence formerly applicable have been considerably relaxed , including in particular the prohibition on letters intended for publication . These new provisions relating to correspondence ( Standing Order M , which also concerns visits ) are available to prisoners .

CARDINAL . Under the terms of Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , every prisoner is allowed to receive visits at intervals laid down by the Secretary of ORG . At the relevant time , Standing Order Ic.CARDINAL provided , inter alia :
" ( CARDINAL ) Every prisoner shall be allowed to receive a visit at least once in DATE and no prisoner shall be deprived of this privilege by a disciplinary award .
( CARDINAL ) Prisoners will be granted the privilege of receiving visits as follows : -

( b ) In the first period of DATE following admission under sentence every prisoner will be eligible to receive CARDINAL visits from relatives or friends . In each subsequent period of DATE he will be eligible to receive CARDINAL visits . "
Paragraph CARDINAL of the Abstract informed prisoners of these provisions regarding the frequency of visits .
The normal duration of a visit was specified under LAW as being TIME , or TIME during DATE of imprisonment ( Standing Order Ic.CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

Governors were given discretion to vary the duration and frequency of visits laid down in the Standing Orders provided the total visiting TIME were not less than specified in the Standing Orders . The arrangement at FAC differed from that laid down in the Standing Orders in that CARDINAL visit of TIME duration per month was permitted in place of the allowance in the Standing Orders of three visits of TIME .
In addition to the ordinary entitlement , ORG was empowered to allow an extra or longer visit in exceptional circumstances ( Rule CARDINAL of the Prison Rules - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . By virtue of Rule CARDINAL ) of ORG , " the Secretary of ORG may authorise the temporary release of prisoners undergoing imprisonment ... for a stated length of time and under conditions and for reasons approved by him " .

Standing Order Jc.CARDINAL sets out the circumstances in which permission may be granted for temporary release on compassionate grounds . Compassionate leave will only be given to visit a near relative who is dangerously ill or to attend the funeral of a near relative . An escort is not normally required for such leave where the prisoner is in Security Category D but is required for other higher security categories .

CARDINAL . A special escorted leave scheme has been operated at ORG for DATE . It is not dealt with in the Standing Orders but a Notice , dated DATE , was issued by the Governor of the Prison explaining the purposes , qualifying conditions and means of operation of the scheme .

The objectives of the scheme are to relieve tension associated with long sentences , to help maintain contact with the home setting , to encourage good relationships between prisoners and staff and to prepare prisoners for eventual release . Only prisoners serving sentences of over DATE are eligible . CARDINAL of the net sentence must have been completed ( or DATE served in the case of a life prisoner ) and the prisoner must have been of satisfactory conduct for a reasonable period . When granted , leave may be taken only if the prisoner is able to obtain the voluntary assistance of a member of staff or an allocated prison visitor ( a voluntary helper ) to act as escorting supervisor . For the first CARDINAL leaves the escort must be a member of staff . Leave is granted on the understanding " that the prisoner places himself under direct supervision throughout the entire period of his absence from prison " . Before going on leave , the prisoner must sign a parole licence acknowledging that he understands the conditions applicable to his period of leave .
CARDINAL . Under LAW scheme at ORG , prior to release prisoners are eligible for the leave entitlement described at paragraph CARDINAL below .
CARDINAL . Under Rule CARDINAL of ORG ,
" ( CARDINAL ) The Secretary of ORG may set aside particular prisons or parts of prisons for particular classes of prisoners or particular purposes , including :
( i ) the special observation of either unconvicted or convicted prisoners for the purpose of classification , making reports to courts , or otherwise ;
( ii ) the training of such classes of prisoners sentenced to imprisonment ... as the Secretary of ORG may from time to time determine .

( CARDINAL ) The Secretary of ORG may establish or set aside prisons for the treatment in open conditions of selected prisoners or classes of prisoners who have been sentenced to imprisonment or corrective training . "

CARDINAL . An open prison has been established at PERSON , which houses CARDINAL prisoners . These prisoners have been individually selected as suitable to serve their sentence in an open prison . Only Category D prisoners can be considered for transfer to PERSON , but the great majority of Category D prisoners are housed , like Mr. PERSON and Mr. PERSON , in closed prisons . The regime at FAC is more liberal than the ordinary regime in closed prisons . In particular :
( i ) prisoners’ mail is not generally read , although the Governor retains discretion to do so ;
( ii ) visits by friends and relatives , though only allowed once DATE , can last for TIME and can be taken in the grounds at the Governor ’s discretion ;
( iii ) prisoners may be granted occasional leave for the purpose of making visits to local residents at their homes .
In other respects , visits and correspondence are subject to the same rules as in other prisons .

CARDINAL . A " special unit " was set up in ORG in DATE to treat prisoners who were known to be violent , prisoners considered potentially violent and selected long - term prisoners . It was sought to modify the traditional officer / inmate relationship by sharing responsibility between prisoners and staff and encouraging them to regard themselves as a single community . The regime in ORG is substantially different from that in other prisons . In particular , mail is not normally censored , although prisoners are expected to observe the normal rules regarding the content of mail and the Governor retains a discretion to read mail . Visiting is not subject to the normal restrictions as regards time , number or duration of visits . There are opportunities for prisoners to go out of the prison . Those in Security Category D may be allowed to do so without escort . ORG has a maximum of CARDINAL prisoners and a CARDINAL - to - CARDINAL ratio of staff to prisoners , as opposed to the ratio of CARDINAL member of staff to CARDINAL prisoners which is more normal elsewhere .

CARDINAL . Both Mr. PERSON and Mr. PERSON were subject to a " Training for Freedom " scheme during the latter stage of their pre - release programme at ORG . Prisoners undergoing such training live in a special hostel within the prison and are given regular temporary release for the purpose of working , community service or attending courses in the GPE area . They are also eligible for QUANTITY unescorted local leave per week and receive CARDINAL full DATE ’s unescorted leave DATE during which they may visit their home .
CARDINAL . The principal remedies available to prisoners in GPE in respect of complaints concerning their treatment in prison are
- a complaint to the Governor of the prison ;
- a complaint to ORG ;
- a petition to the Secretary of ORG ;
- a complaint to the Parliamentary Commissioner for ORG ;
- an application to the courts for judicial review .

CARDINAL . By virtue of Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG , any request by a prisoner to see , inter alia , the Governor or a member of ORG must be recorded by the officer to whom it is made and conveyed without delay to the Governor . Under Rule CARDINAL ) , the Governor is obliged at a fixed time DATE other than DATE and DATE to see all prisoners who have requested to see him .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW lays down that the Prison Rules shall provide for the constitution of Visiting Committees . The relevant provision is made in LAW . Members of ORG for each prison are appointed by the regional , district and island councils - which are composed of elected representatives - in the area served by the prison ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . Visiting Committees and their members are independent of the prison administration . Section CARDINAL ) of the LAW specifies that the Prison Rules shall prescribe the functions of Visiting Committees and furthermore that

" [ the Rules ] shall among other things require the members to pay frequent visits to the prison and hear any complaints which may be made by the prisoners and report to the Secretary of ORG any matter which they consider it expedient to report ; and any member of ORG may at any time enter the prison and shall have free access to every part thereof and to every prisoner " .
CARDINAL . Rules CARDINAL to CARDINAL of the Prison Rules deal with the procedures and functions of ORG . In particular , Rule CARDINAL reads :

" ( CARDINAL ) ORG shall hear and investigate any application or complaint which any prisoner may desire to make to them ; and , if necessary , report the same , with their opinion , to the Secretary of ORG . They shall have free access to all parts of the prison and to all prisoners , and may see any such prisoners as they desire , either in their cells or in a room out of sight and hearing of prison officers .
( CARDINAL ) ORG shall record in TIME their findings on all such applications or complaints investigated by them , and the result of all visits to , and inspections of , the prison . "

Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) entitles prisoners to write in confidence to ORG . Rule CARDINAL lays down the general requirement that ORG " shall immediately bring to the notice of the Secretary of ORG any circumstances connected with the administration of the prison which appear to them to require his consideration " .

Rule CARDINAL empowers ORG " in any case of special importance or urgency " to " allow a prisoner an additional visit or letter or prolong the period of a visit " . By virtue of Rule CARDINAL , ORG must , before granting any permission ( such as leave for an additional visit ) , consult the prison Governor in order to satisfy themselves that it can be granted without interfering with the security , good order , and government of the prison .

CARDINAL . Inmates have the right to submit petitions to the Secretary of ORG about any matter , for example to seek a permission which the local prison management is not empowered to grant or has refused , or to complain of prison treatment . There is no restriction on the number or frequency of petitions which a prisoner may make to the Secretary of ORG on the same or different matters . On a petition being made by a prisoner , complaining of a decision of the prison authorities , the Secretary of ORG would , if he concluded that the relevant Rules or Standing Orders had not been properly interpreted or applied by the prison authorities , issue directions to them to secure compliance . Although it is possible for him to depart from the Standing Orders in particular cases , this is likely to occur only rarely , if at all , since their very purpose is to ensure uniformity of practice .
Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Prison Rules provides :

" Every prisoner intimating to an officer his desire to write a letter of request or complaint to the Secretary of ORG or ORG shall be supplied with paper for the purpose , and the Governor shall see that every such letter is posted without delay . If the prisoner has elected to close the envelope it shall not be opened by the Governor . "
Standing Order Jb.CARDINAL stipulates that " a prisoner wishing to submit a petition to the Secretary of ORG shall apply to the Governor . No such application shall be refused " .

CARDINAL . The Parliamentary Commissioner for ORG ( commonly known as the ORG ) has jurisdiction under LAW DATE to investigate complaints of " maladministration " in Government Departments . Such complaints may be raised with him by any Member of ORG and , since DATE , the Commissioner has been prepared to refer to a Member of ORG and consider complaints raised directly with him by members of the public , including prisoners . He must report on investigations he makes both to the Member of ORG concerned and also to the head of the relevant ORG and may make appropriate recommendations . He also reports periodically to ORG on his activities . Any departure from the statutory or administrative rules governing the regulation of prisons may amount to maladministration . However , his jurisdiction does not extend to restrictions effected pursuant to a correct exercise of a discretion conferred by the ORG or the Secretary of ORG ’s directives . The Parliamentary Commissioner may , where he considers that his investigation shows that injustice has been caused by maladministration and that it has not been or will not be remedied , lay before each ORG of ORG a special report on the case . In practice , the ORG concerned will normally seek to remedy any injustice found .

CARDINAL . The exercise by public authorities of statutory powers and duties is subject to review by the courts . The grounds on which judicial review may be open are in substance the same in GPE as in GPE and GPE ( see PERSON v. ORG , DATE ORG , CARDINAL , per Lord PERSON at p. CARDINAL ) . In particular , an exercise of discretionary power may be challenged on the grounds that the authority concerned has acted arbitrarily , in bad faith , unreasonably , for an improper purpose or otherwise outside its statutory powers ( see , for example , the speech of Lord PERSON in ORG Unions v. Minister for ORG [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL at CARDINAL and [ DATE ] CARDINAL All England Law Reports CARDINAL at CARDINAL - CARDINAL , as quoted in the DATE judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ) .

The Government cited CARDINAL cases , both subsequent to the facts complained of in the present proceedings , as examples of the courts adjudicating on the lawfulness of ORG treatment in the light of the statutory powers and duties of the prison authorities . In the case of PERSON v. PERSON ( [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL and [ DATE ] CARDINAL All England Law Reports CARDINAL ) , ORG held that FAC and the relevant Standing Orders would be ultra vires and invalid in so far as they purported to restrict a prisoner ’s right to unimpeded access to the courts since that right could only be taken away by express enactment . In NORP v. Deputy Governor of PERSON , ex parte King ( [ DATE ] CARDINAL All England Law Reports CARDINAL ) , ORG decided that a prison Governor ’s decision on disciplinary matters was not open to judicial review . ORG explained that if a prisoner has a well - founded complaint that a Governor has misconstrued a Prison Rule the appropriate method to seek redress is to petition the Secretary of ORG inviting attention to the misconstruction , and then if the Secretary of ORG rejects the petition he may apply for judicial review of the Secretary of ORG ’s decision in the form of a declaration as to the correct construction ( ibid . , pp . CARDINAL , FAC and CARDINAL ) .
